awd_titl_txt: Probing and directing colloidal migration by sculpting chemical micro-environments
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET 1438779

Many materials of industrial and biological importance consist of small colloidal particles suspended in a liquid.  The particles are so small that they move in response to various forces exerted on them by their surroundings.  This project will study diffusiophoresis, which is the motion of colloidal particles in response to concentration variations of a dissolved solute such as salt in the liquid.  A microfluidic-based device will be developed that can create and maintain solute concentration gradients in a liquid.  Then, the motion of colloidal particles in the liquid will be observed directly and correlated with the direction and magnitude of the concentration gradient. A variety of particles and different kinds of solute concentration gradients will be examined.  Although there have been theories developed to explain diffusiophoresis, there are few experiments available to test those theories.  The results will help scientists and engineers formulate and process colloidal suspensions that are used in a variety of industries.  The project will provide research training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students and will engage elementary school students in demonstrations of engineering principles and applications.

Although colloidal diffusiophoresis plays a central role in industrial and coating processes, and is common around equilibrating or reacting surfaces, it is less well understood than other migration phenomena such as electrophoresis.  Direct measurements of diffusiophoretic mobilities are confounded by the challenges of establishing strong, stable, convection-free gradients in macroscopic systems.  This project will use a microfluidic device that has hydrogel micro-window membranes integrated into its channel walls.  The hydrogel windows are permeable to solute and solvent diffusion.  Diffusion through the windows will allow spatial and temporal solute gradients to be established and maintained across selected channels of the device.  An interferometric technique will be used to measure solute concentration, and colloidal diffusiophoretic mobility will be measured by direct observation of particle motion.  The device will also be equipped to measure electrophoretic mobility of the same colloid.  New phoretic phenomena will be identified and exploited for direct assembly of structure soft materials.

por.por_cntn:
Suspensions of micron-scale particles and drops are ubiquitous in complex fluid formulations like foods, consumer products, pharmaceuticals, paints, coatings, and other materials and precursors.  The success or failure of these products depends crucially on how the particles interact: it is good for milk to curdle when making cheese, but not when a microbial community has taken root.  

A number of equilibrium interactions have long been exploited to stabilize these suspensions and tune the properties of the materials.  This project involves diffusiophoresis, which is a non-equilibrium phenomenon in which suspended particles migrate in response to solutes diffusing in inhomogeneous concentration fields.  Although diffusiophoresis was first described almost 70 years ago, direct experimental tests have been challenging because gradients strong enough to drive appreciable diffusiophoresis in a lab-scale system simultaneously introduce density gradients, and thus cause fluid flows that overwhelm the effect.  While it may seem like this would make the effect unimportant in any real-world application, there is often a small stagnant layer around electrodes and surfaces across which such gradients arise, which can impact the deposition of paints or foulants onto surfaces, for good or for bad.

This project advanced scientific understanding of colloidal migration and diffusiophoresis in multiple ways, and developed powerful new experimental tools to do so.  Working with microfabricated fluidic devices avoided the buoyancy-driven convection that hampers larger-scale experiments.  Moreover, we developed hydrogel microwindow membranes (HMMs) that can be integrated naturally in place of microchannel walls, and that function like microdialysis membranes:  HMM pores are small enough that the membrane looks like a rigid wall to a flowing fluid, but large enough that small molecules (salt ions, solvent molecules, sugars) can diffuse through it (figure 1).  Flowing different solutions behind each HMM enable chemical concentration fields to be sculpted; for example, a stable concentration gradient can be imposed, and the migration velocity of suspended particles can be visualized directly.

This system enabled the direct visualization and systematic characterization of colloidal migration under a host of chemical gradients. (figure 2) These studies directly validated classic theories for salt-driven migration, and revealed complications and subtleties that arise in gradients of surfactants, solvents, and zwitterions.  

To follow the concentration fields sculpted by HMMs, we developed a powerful new technique to track concentration profiles in space and time using microfluidic interferometry.  A benefit of the technique is that the molecules do not need to be labelled (e.g. with a fluorescent tag) to be tracked.  In addition to these sculpting measurements, we have used the technique to measure the reaction kinetics of the interfacial polymerization process used to make reverse osmosis membranes, which had not been possible previously because the reaction occurs within tens of nanometers, and completes within tens of seconds.  

The experimental and conceptual advances on diffusiophoretic migration helped to advance a conceptually new non-equilibrium soluto-inertial interaction we developed.  The concept is to make a soluto-inertial beacon that preferentially absorbs some solute; then slowly releases it when placed into a suspension of particles or drops.  As the solute diffuses away from the beacon, it drives the particles or drops to move diffusiophoretically, either toward or away from the beacon.  This basic idea is enough to develop a conceptual, intuitive framework to understand, design, and manipulate these chemical fluxes — to drive particles into or out of dead-end pores; to deliver particles to targets hidden within porous media (fig. 3), or to collect a certain type of suspended particles from millimeters away. (fig. 4)

This project provided primary and partial support for four graduate students and three undergraduates; sixteen peer-reviewed papers were published in the scientific literature and its results have been presented in a wide variety of national and international conferences, workshops, symposia and seminars.
